text: Hi <@UV6F64HPG> - although we cannot predict the start time, we have added additional services (<https://docs.developer.betfair.com/display/1smk3cen4v3lu3yomq5qye0ni/Race+Status+API|Race Status API>) over the years to give a better indication of how close horses are to the start line (Going Down, Going Behind, etc).  However, this itself is subject to these updates being received in a timely manner from the feed source provider.

text:
Would Betfair be willing to provide accurate(ish - down to millisecond precision) internal timestamps in responses and in the stream?
1. When I send a bet in-play, for example in horse racing, I get a 'pending' response, but this response doesn't include the timestamp that the order was received at the Betfair server. This timestamp must exist in order for Betfair's tech to know in which sequence all orders were received. It would be great to have this timestamp included in the pending response, so that I can measure my latency "from door to door" accurately.
2. On the market data stream we receive a 'publishTime' which is presumably the time at which the matching engine cycle finished. It would also be useful to have a field that represents the time at which the matching engine cycle began. This would enable me to look back at the logs and say: OK, my order didn't arrive in time to make it into this matching cycle which began at T1, so it was delayed a bit longer and had to wait for the next one, which began at time T2.

elements.text: Would Betfair be willing to provide accurate(ish - down to millisecond precision) internal timestamps in responses and in the stream?

When I send a bet in-play, for example in horse racing, I get a 'pending' response, but this response doesn't include the timestamp that the order was received at the Betfair server. This timestamp must exist in order for Betfair's tech to know in which sequence all orders were received. It would be great to have this timestamp included in the pending response, so that I can measure my latency "from door to door" accurately.

On the market data stream we receive a 'publishTime' which is presumably the time at which the matching engine cycle finished. It would also be useful to have a field that represents the time at which the matching engine cycle began. This would enable me to look back at the logs and say: OK, my order didn't arrive in time to make it into this matching cycle which began at T1, so it was delayed a bit longer and had to wait for the next one, which began at time T2.

text: Hi <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> - it's rare that outages are caused by the same reoccurring issue. I can confirm that the most recent issues weren’t within the Stream API layer itself, but due to us not being able to load/manage markets. Therefore, we had to bring the Exchange down while the root cause of the issue was investigated. We don’t expect a repeat of the same issue.

elements.text: Hi

- it's rare that outages are caused by the same reoccurring issue. I can confirm that the most recent issues weren’t within the Stream API layer itself, but due to us not being able to load/manage markets. Therefore, we had to bring the Exchange down while the root cause of the issue was investigated. We don’t expect a repeat of the same issue.

text: Hi <@UBS7QANF3> - yes it is possible for a bet to be placed if a TIMEOUT occurs.  See the below guidance from the API docs regarding this - _"The order timed out & the status of the bet is unknown. * *If a TIMEOUT error occurs on a *placeOrders/replaceOrders* request, you should check *listCurrentOrders* to verify the status of your bets before placing further orders. *Please Note:* Timeouts will occur after 5 seconds of attempting to process the bet but please allow up to 15 seconds for a timed out order to appear. After this time any unprocessed bets will automatically be Lapsed and no longer be available on the Exchange."_

elements.text: Hi
- yes it is possible for a bet to be placed if a TIMEOUT occurs.  See the below guidance from the API docs regarding this -
"The order timed out & the status of the bet is unknown.
If a TIMEOUT error occurs on a
placeOrders/replaceOrders
request, you should check
listCurrentOrders
to verify the status of your bets before placing further orders.
Please Note:

Timeouts will occur after 5 seconds of attempting to process the bet but please allow up to 15 seconds for a timed out order to appear. After this time any unprocessed bets will automatically be Lapsed and no longer be available on the Exchange."

text: If there were mass adoption of CFD it would increase incentives to manipulate market prices for the purposes of manipulating CFDs. It would exacerbate the problem. Spoofing is problematic, but has nowhere close to the same level  of impact. With CFD manipulation you have a customer who may make a reasonable bet, but gets shafted after the fact due to manipulation. The customer has no way to mitigate this problem, and thus the offering itself is fundamentally flawed. CFDs are an interesting idea, but with the fractured liquidity due to so many sporting events (as opposed to fewer stocks/currencies/etc), I don't think it can work.

text: I guess it would be tricky initially and maybe a non started in a few market types but it sounds like there is no apatite for these which is a separate issue. I still think what your describing is what is possible today with bets (as thats how they would have to do it). It must be too costly otherwise people would be doing it with bets, back one horse into 1.01 so you can match at 1000 on the others. The markets would in theory be multiple times larger then their current size assuming people still target the same exposure. Id personally love it for horses.

text: At the risk of appearing a dunce, how does this work in practice? If your bet is unable to be matched immediately then it appears in the market, and if it can be matched immediately the delay is applied? If so you can detect a match from a delayed response to your bet being placed? Just struggling to get my head around the actual chain of events as part of this potential change, particularly in something fast moving inplay like racing where you can get matched much higher than your ask price.

text:
A while back there were a few users on here that got blocked and didn't seem to know why, obviously Betfair have certain legal obligations that can't be avoided and have to adhere to these, but aside from that, when permissible by local laws (i.e. when its not AML related basically), it would be good if users were given a warning if their betting behaviour would be likely to cause them to be blocked (e.g. an e-mail warning saying you are making an excessive number of REST API calls without placing sufficient bets or something to that effect).

In essence it would hopefully be mutually beneficial to allow people to change behaviour, rather than taking the nuclear option and closing down accounts without warning.

I should stress I have no idea what actually happens/happened in these situations personally, I'm just going on what people have posted.

So I guess the question is, would it be possible to have a slightly more formalised / structured approach to this type of occurrence to provide piece of mind that no-one is going to get shut down without just cause?

elements.text:
A while back there were a few users on here that got blocked and didn't seem to know why, obviously Betfair have certain legal obligations that can't be avoided and have to adhere to these, but aside from that, when permissible by local laws (i.e. when its not AML related basically), it would be good if users were given a warning if their betting behaviour would be likely to cause them to be blocked (e.g. an e-mail warning saying you are making an excessive number of REST API calls without placing sufficient bets or something to that effect).

In essence it would hopefully be mutually beneficial to allow people to change behaviour, rather than taking the nuclear option and closing down accounts without warning.

I should stress I have no idea what actually happens/happened in these situations personally, I'm just going on what people have posted.

So I guess the question is, would it be possible to have a slightly more formalised / structured approach to this type of occurrence to provide piece of mind that no-one is going to get shut down without just cause?

text:
Hi <@UCQB6S222> - thanks for your feedback on this.

*Regarding #1* – The PENDING status on placeOrders is returned for an asynchronous order is yet to be processed. This means that the bet has passed the validation stage, but has yet to have a betId assigned, which takes place once the bet has been processed successfully by the matching engine. Once the bet has been processed and placed, the timestamp (placedDate) is provided via listCurrentOrders and the Order Stream. We don’t have any specific plans to provide additional timestamps.   The idea of async bet placement is to remove any waiting time associated with the matching process/bet delay to immediately free up connections.

elements.text: Hi
- thanks for your feedback on this.
Regarding #1

– The PENDING status on placeOrders is returned for an asynchronous order is yet to be processed. This means that the bet has passed the validation stage, but has yet to have a betId assigned, which takes place once the bet has been processed successfully by the matching engine. Once the bet has been processed and placed, the timestamp (placedDate) is provided via listCurrentOrders and the Order Stream. We don’t have any specific plans to provide additional timestamps.   The idea of async bet placement is to remove any waiting time associated with the matching process/bet delay to immediately free up connections.

text: *#2* - The publishedTime is the time a new message is created and sent.  A message is created and the published time is set immediately prior to sending.  Understand that having more information relating to the matching cycle would be interesting, but is this a "nice to have" or would this have a fundamental impact on your behavior?  If you have queries relating to specific bet placement times (etc) we are able to check and confirm betId processing times from our logs.

elements.text: - The publishedTime is the time a new message is created and sent.  A message is created and the published time is set immediately prior to sending.  Understand that having more information relating to the matching cycle would be interesting, but is this a "nice to have" or would this have a fundamental impact on your behavior?  If you have queries relating to specific bet placement times (etc) we are able to check and confirm betId processing times from our logs.

text:
Hi <@UNW8Q88EL>, thanks very much for getting back to me with this impressively comprehensive response, which is much appreciated, and thanks again for this initiative which is brilliant I think we all agree.
A few things come to mind:
• I probably phrased question 1 in a misleading way. I didn't mean to sound as if I was asking about asynchronous orders. I am really just interested to know how best to measure latency from door to door - and I am sure others would be too. Your thoughts on that would be greatly appreciated.
• Something like placedDate is _*possibly*_ what I am looking for, and I should have mentioned it as a possible solution. However, it currently doesn't help because it seems to be rounded to the nearest second or at least doesn't display any precision further than that at all, which is frustrating.
• Furthermore, even if placedDate was a millisecond-precise quantity it's not entirely clear (to me) what the meaning of this value actually is. Does it describe the time that the order arrived at Betfair's servers, or does it represent the time that the order was considered by the matching engine perhaps?
• In terms of question 2, I suppose what I am really after is a way to figure out exactly how much slower my order was than the one which got the fill that I wanted. Let's say a horse falls and I want to be the first to lay it. So I send a LAY order to Betfair, but it doesn't get filled, because someone else was faster. It's pretty hard in this situation for me to know whether I "lost" the race for liquidity by 1 millisecond or 200 milliseconds. I can look at the publishTime of the stream update which shows the successful order, but there's no way to track that successful order backwards in time to know what time it arrived at Betfair's server compared to what time my order arrived. I was just thinking that, if I knew how long the specific matching cycle in question had taken, that would enable me to work backwards and make a good estimate of when the successful order arrived. And, if I also had a good idea of what time my order arrived, then the difference between the two represents how much I lost the race by. 
• If I'm going to lose the race by 200ms then I may as well give up; if I'm mostly losing by 20ms then I should probably carry on trying and maybe invest in some better technology!

elements.text: Hi

, thanks very much for getting back to me with this impressively comprehensive response, which is much appreciated, and thanks again for this initiative which is brilliant I think we all agree.
A few things come to mind:

I probably phrased question 1 in a misleading way. I didn't mean to sound as if I was asking about asynchronous orders. I am really just interested to know how best to measure latency from door to door - and I am sure others would be too. Your thoughts on that would be greatly appreciated.
Something like placedDate is
possibly

what I am looking for, and I should have mentioned it as a possible solution. However, it currently doesn't help because it seems to be rounded to the nearest second or at least doesn't display any precision further than that at all, which is frustrating.

Furthermore, even if placedDate was a millisecond-precise quantity it's not entirely clear (to me) what the meaning of this value actually is. Does it describe the time that the order arrived at Betfair's servers, or does it represent the time that the order was considered by the matching engine perhaps?

In terms of question 2, I suppose what I am really after is a way to figure out exactly how much slower my order was than the one which got the fill that I wanted. Let's say a horse falls and I want to be the first to lay it. So I send a LAY order to Betfair, but it doesn't get filled, because someone else was faster. It's pretty hard in this situation for me to know whether I "lost" the race for liquidity by 1 millisecond or 200 milliseconds. I can look at the publishTime of the stream update which shows the successful order, but there's no way to track that successful order backwards in time to know what time it arrived at Betfair's server compared to what time my order arrived. I was just thinking that, if I knew how long the specific matching cycle in question had taken, that would enable me to work backwards and make a good estimate of when the successful order arrived. And, if I also had a good idea of what time my order arrived, then the difference between the two represents how much I lost the race by.
If I'm going to lose the race by 200ms then I may as well give up; if I'm mostly losing by 20ms then I should probably carry on trying and maybe invest in some better technology!

text: Hi <@U4H19D1D2> - we conduct an internal Post-Incident Review (PIR) when an outage takes place, focusing on establishing the root cause + recommendations to prevent the same issue from happening again, and decreasing the time of resolution.  Always interested to know what you think would be useful for us to provide, and the best way to disseminate this.  In the past, we have provided further information regarding major incidents and remedial actions via the Premium Newsletter  - but don't do this as a matter of course for every incident,

text: Ok, from my side it would be helpful to know what wrong so that I can better prepare for something similar. From writing tests to changing logic to make code more resilient, often things break but can be hard to fix/replicate after the fact due to not even knowing what caused it

text:
There is room for a more in-depth & definitive technical article on this, so I’ll see if our dev team will consider writing something to be included on our Technology blog (<https://ppb.technology>). We might not be able to provide the full and more explicit technical details you want though :slightly_smiling_face:

In the meantime, here’s a high-level summary:
 
• For performance reasons, all bet matching takes place in a bulk betting matching cycle, each of which takes ~100 m/s. 
• All bets within a single cycle are queued (matched/unmatched) on a FIFO basis. 
• Cross-matching occurs both at the market and event level. 
• There is no concept of exactly the same time, one bet will always be picked up before another even if one is microseconds before the other.

elements.text: There is room for a more in-depth & definitive technical article on this, so I’ll see if our dev team will consider writing something to be included on our Technology blog (
). We might not be able to provide the full and more explicit technical details you want though
In the meantime, here’s a high-level summary:
For performance reasons, all bet matching takes place in a bulk betting matching cycle, each of which takes ~100 m/s.
All bets within a single cycle are queued (matched/unmatched) on a FIFO basis.
Cross-matching occurs both at the market and event level.
There is no concept of exactly the same time, one bet will always be picked up before another even if one is microseconds before the other.

text: It's a nice protection for a market maker. Some financial exchanges have similar things (post-only order types, even order types that expire based on some market move indicator on the exchange side). 100% of my volume is currently passive so it very much fits my style.
